item.title: Praise and Skepticism as One Executive Sets Minimum Wage to $70,000 a Year
item.description: While the overwhelming majority of the responses on social media and elsewhere were positive, there were also a number of skeptics and naysayers.
item.dc:creator: PATRICIA COHEN
item.media:credit: Matthew Ryan Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dan Price, standing, the chief executive of Gravity, with employees. His pledge to raise the minimum wage to $70,000 a year at his company has riled skeptics and naysayers.

item.title: Blood Test Shows Promise as Alternative to Cancer Biopsy
item.description: The hope is to give oncologists a tool to let them figure out quickly whether a treatment is working and, if it is, to keep monitoring for resistance.
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA

item.title: ArtsBeat: ‘Furious 7’ Muscles Out Newcomers
item.description: A “Paul Blart” sequel and the horror film “Unfriended” settled for second and third place.
item.dc:creator: BROOKS BARNES

item.title: ISIS Video Purports to Show Killing of Ethiopian Christians
item.description: The footage, if confirmed, would be the first evidence that the Islamic State’s leaders in Syria and Iraq are coordinating with fighters who have taken up the group’s banner in southern and eastern Libya.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A video released on Sunday by the Islamic State appears to show fighters from affiliates in southern and eastern Libya executing dozens of Ethiopian Christians.

item.title: The Working Life: A Response to Alec Baldwin’s Complaints That a Living Wage Rally Snarled Traffic
item.description: The actor Alec Baldwin took to Twitter to grouse about gridlock in Manhattan caused by demonstrators seeking a $15 minimum wage.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL L. SWARNS
item.media:description: Demonstrators participating in a "die in" in front of a McDonald's restaurant in Manhattan during rallies on Wednesday seeking higher wages in New York.

item.title: At Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Ceremony, a Generational Push and Pull
item.description: Even with a millennial ambassador like Miley Cyrus on stage, the ceremony was about holding up — and keeping a tight grip on — consensus icons of the art form, like the late Lou Reed.
item.category: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum
item.dc:creator: JOE COSCARELLI
item.media:description: Joan Jett, left, one of this year’s Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees, was joined onstage by Tommy James, center, and Miley Cyrus, who introduced Ms. Jett at the induction ceremony on Saturday night in Cleveland.

item.title: Hundreds Feared Dead After Boat Filled With Migrants Capsizes in Mediterranean
item.description: The boat overturned 70 miles north of Libya as a Portuguese vessel that the Italian authorities had diverted was approaching it early Sunday, the Italian Coast Guard said.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: A New Whitney
item.description: No longer a fortress in an uneasy city, the Whitney Museum of American Art opens itself up to a changed New York, a glittery emblem signaling a definitive shift in the city’s social geography. The Times’s architecture critic Michael Kimmelman reviews.

item.title: IS Video Purports to Show Killing of Ethiopians in Libya
item.description: A video released by the Islamic State group on Sunday appears to show the killing of two different groups of captured Ethiopian Christians by the extremist group's Libyan affiliates.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 24 Dead, 28 Safe, Hundreds Missing as Med Migrant Boat Sinks
item.description: A boat crowded with migrants capsized in the sea north of Libya overnight, leaving at least 24 confirmed dead with the death toll expected to rise into the hundreds, Italy's Coast Guard said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Up to 700 Feared Dead After Migrant Boat Sinks Off Libya: UNHCR
item.description: As many as 700 people are feared dead after a boat carrying migrants capsized off the Libyan coast overnight, a United Nations official said on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: BuzzFeed Says Posts Were Deleted Because of Advertising Pressure
item.description: At least three posts out of more than 1,000 were erased after employees from the company’s business side complained about their content, according to a memo from BuzzFeed’s editor.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Jim Cramer Marries Lisa Detwiler
item.description: The normally histrionic host of “Mad Money With Jim Cramer” was surprisingly charming on his first date with his future bride.
item.dc:creator: VINCENT M. MALLOZZI

item.title: First Draft: At Candidate Forum, Walker Discusses Same-Sex Marriage of a Relative
item.description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a likely Republican presidential candidate, addressed an issue on Saturday night that has been roiling his party in recent years: gay marriage.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: PATRICK HEALY
item.media:credit: Ian Thomas Jansen-Lonnquist for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a likely Republican presidential candidate, said he attended a reception for a gay relative who had been married.

item.title: A. Alfred Taubman, Former Sotheby’s Owner and Mall Developer, Dies at 91
item.description: The retail tycoon, who turned Sotheby’s into a global power for art sales, went to prison in a price-fixing scandal involving Christie’s that, prosecutors said, cheated buyers and sellers out of $100 million.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT D. McFADDEN
item.media:credit: Frances Roberts for The New York Times
item.media:description: A. Alfred Taubman, then chairman of Sotheby’s, after being sentenced at Federal District Court in Manhattan in 2002 for his role in a price-fixing conspiracy with Christie’s auction house.

item.title: Workers Seeking Productivity in a Pill Are Abusing A.D.H.D. Drugs
item.description: Interviews with users and treatment experts suggest a growing number of young American workers are taking stimulants to enhance concentration and stamina at work.
item.category: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration
item.dc:creator: ALAN SCHWARZ
item.media:credit: Elizabeth D. Herman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elizabeth, a Long Island native identified by her middle name, with her Adderall.

item.title: Lawyers for Tulsa Reserve Deputy in Fatal Shooting Release Training Records
item.description: The lawyers released some of the training records Saturday for the volunteer sheriff’s deputy charged with manslaughter in the fatal shooting of an unarmed man in Oklahoma.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Solar Power Battle Puts Hawaii at Forefront of Worldwide Changes
item.description: As homemade electricity gains popularity, it puts new pressures on old infrastructure and cuts into electric company revenue, pitting solar companies against utilities.
item.dc:creator: DIANE CARDWELL
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Household panels for solar power and hot water in Kapolei, Hawaii. Installing new electrical panels was blocked there until recently.

item.title: Conflict Over Soil and Water Quality Puts ‘Iowa Nice’ to a Test
item.description: The state’s largest utility has sued three rural counties, saying they have done too little to prevent nitrates from farmland from getting into drinking water.
item.dc:creator: MITCH SMITH
item.media:credit: Ryan Donnell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brent Johnson straddling a tilled field and wetlands on his farm in Calhoun County, Iowa, one of three counties that have been sued over nitrates seeping into water supplies.

item.title: Sale of U.S. Arms Fuels the Wars of Arab States
item.description: A de facto alliance in the region against Iran has opened the way to more sales to Arab states, and raised fears of an arms race.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Qatar is seeking to purchase Boeing F-15 fighters to replace its aging French Mirage jets, above.
